results.title: Serie Noire
results.brief_description:
Frank Poupart is 30 year old loser who works as a door-to-door salesman in a dreary suburban wasteland. While doing his rounds, he sells a dressing gown to an old woman. The woman says she can’t pay but offers Frank to spend time with her teenage niece as a ‘compensation’. Mona and Frank become lovers, and both of them see a way out of their impoverished dead-end existences when Mona tells him that her aunt has a large stash of money hidden away. Director Alain Corneau cited Fritz Lang and American film noir as major influences for this film. The setting of ‘Serie Noire’ is bleak and wintry: vacant lots and blocks of flats, deserted except for the central characters. Much of the film is shot in shabby interiors or in Frank’s car, itself a restricted space from which he cannot escape. The soundtrack adds to the sense of realism, comprising the rumble of thunder and traffic, and incessant pop music from the radios which are found in almost every scene. Perec [the scriptwriter] has Frank speak a mixture of French backslang (le verlan) and street slang, combined with Anglicisms and spoonerisms. As Corneau remarked: “The challenge was to give an appearance of naturalism, but at all costs to avoid succumbing to it: we had to do something totally unrealistic.” Consequently, when Frank tries to express himself, he is at odds with reality, and in his mouth even the most banal language is turned around and used obliquely. Frank’s monologues, uttered in despair or frenzy while imprisoned in his car, are his own attempt to talk himself away from ‘la zone’.” Reference: Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French Cinema: an introduction’. Manchester University Press, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Maurice Bernart ; director, Alain Corneau ; writers, Georges Perec, Alain Corneau ; photography, Pierre-William Glenn ; music, Duke Ellington, Juan Tizol.
Cast: Patrick Dewaere, Myriam Boyer, Bernard Blier, Marie Trintignant, Andreas Katsulas, Jeanne Herviale.

results.title: Serial Mom
results.creator_credit: John Waters, Mark Tarlov, John Fiedler and Polar Entertainment
results.brief_description: A combination of Mrs Brady and Murphy Brown, Beverly Sutphin (Kathleen Turner) is fiercely protective of her family, she will do anything to ensure their happiness, anything! She’s an active member of the PTA, a devoted wife to her dentist husband and a great housekeeper. She is “Super Mom”. Still waters, however, run deep and beneath the surface lies a multitude of secrets. Mom isn’t all she’s cracked up to be. Her son’s teacher suddenly disappears after recommending therapy for the boy to deal with his obsession for gore. Her daughter’s boyfriend winds up dead after he fails to call her when he said he would. The one of Dad’s patients forgets to floss and pays the ultimate price.

results.title: Serial experiments: Lain. Vol. 04: reset
results.creator_credit: Akihiko Nishiyama, Johei Matsuura, Ryutaro Nakamura, Haruyo Kanesaku, Yutaka Maseba, Hiroe Tsukamoto, Genco and Pioneer LDCE
results.brief_description: Finale of the animated Japanese series, “Lain”; Volume 04 “Reset”, episodes (layers) 11, 12 and 13. Lain is an introverted thirteen year old schoolgirl who is drawn into the world of “The Wired” (a euphemism for the Internet), an alternate reality where minds roam freely unencumbered by their mortal body. Episode 11, “Infornography”: in an increasingly disoriented existence, Lain is perplexed as to whether she exists at all. Episode 12, “Landscape”: realising she is a multiple presence, Lain struggles to comprehend the dark forces that are enabling the Wired to become connected to the real world. Episode 13, “Ego”: “Where is the real me?” asks Lain, in this final instalment of the series. If Lain deletes herself in the Wired, she may fail to exist at all. Conceptually, “Lain” is comparable to the classic definition of cyberpunk - a paranoid moral and psychological parable that centres on the relationships between people and technology.

results.title: Serial experiments: Lain. Vol. 03: deus
results.creator_credit: Akihiko Nishiyama, Johei Matsuura, Ryutaro Nakamura, Haruyo Kanesaku, Yutaka Maseba, Hiroe Tsukamoto, Genco and Pioneer LDCE
results.brief_description: Continuation of the Japanese animated series “Lain”, Volume 03 “Deus”, episodes (layers) 8, 9 and 10. Lain is an introverted thirteen year old schoolgirl who is drawn into the world of “The Wired” (a euphemism for the Internet), an alternate reality where minds roam freely unencumbered by their mortal body. Episode 8, “Rumours in the Wired”: Lain reveals her aggressive alter ego whilst trying to ascertain whether there is a God. Meanwhile, Lain in the real world becomes increasingly frightened and attempts to wrestle control of her life. Episode 9, “Protocol”: in this episode the history of computers that lead to the establishment of the Wired is explained; Lain confronts Taro, suspecting that he is a Knight. Episode 10, “Love”: Lain comes face-to-face with God in the Wired. Conceptually, “Lain” is comparable to the classic definition of cyberpunk - a paranoid moral and psychological parable that centres on the relationships between people and technology.

results.title: Serial experiments: Lain. Vol. 02: knights
results.creator_credit: Akihiko Nishiyama, Johei Matsuura, Ryutaro Nakamura, Haruyo Kanesaku, Yutaka Maseba, Hiroe Tsukamoto, Genco and Pioneer LDCE
results.brief_description: Continuation of the animated Japanese series, “Lain”, Volume 02 “Knights”, episodes (layers) 5, 6 and 7. Lain is an introverted thirteen year old schoolgirl who is drawn into the world of “The Wired” (a euphemism for the Internet), an alternate reality where minds roam freely unencumbered by their mortal body. Episode 5, “Distortion”: Lain receives communication from mysterious forces about the workings of the Wired, intensifying her powers within the cyber network. As her life becomes progressively stranger, Lain starts to question the bounds of reality as her sister is beset by visions and warnings to fulfil a mysterious prophecy. Episode 6, “Kids”: Lain discovers that a rash of teen suicides is connected to a game played in the Wired. Inured to the world of the Wired, Lain is increasingly isolated from the real world. Episode 7 “Society”: when Lain’s existence is threatened by the ‘Knights’, she enlists the help of the men in black who have been trailing her. Conceptually, “Lain” is comparable to the classic definition of cyberpunk - a paranoid moral and psychological parable that centres on the relationships between people and technology.

results.title: The Locket
results.brief_description:
It would be easy to discard a worthless, old locket found on the beach but, out of respect for a serviceman in a black and white photo, an old man embarks on a journey to return the memento to its original owner. He travels a long way from his lonely, daily routine and unearths respect for himself and a fallen solider. ‘The Locket’ is a snapshot of a life we don’t know we’re in until something – or someone – snaps you out of it.
Cast Includes: John Murphy, Iris Whitakker, David Jellie, Victoria Upward, Gomer Jones and Nadine Crichton.
Under the category ‘Secondary Live Action’, this independent entry by Blake Borcich, Year 10, was the Screen It 2011 winner.

results.title: Sergeant York
results.creator_credit: Howard Hawks, Hal B. Wallis, Jesse L Lasky and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: He was a pacifist, turned patriot; a backwoods farmboy and ace Turkey Shoot champ who decided there are some things worth fighting for. Sergeant Alvin C. York became the renowned hero of World War I, capturing 132 German soldiers during the savage fighting in the Argonne. York insisted that if a film was to be made of his life, he wanted Gary Cooper only to play his character. This performance earned Cooper an Oscar. Under the direction of Howard Hawks, and with a cast that included Walter Brennan and Joan Leslie, this film will remain an all time classic.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Howard Hawks, Hal B. Wallis, Jesse L Lasky and Warner Bros Pictures

results.title: The Respect Quest [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Christopher Halse, Liam Blake and Tea Tree Gully Primary School
results.brief_description:
Time Monsters are spreading disrespect in the community and causing havoc. Help local villagers and elders restore respect by defeating the Time Monsters with a magic boomerang. Jump on platforms, collect coins and explore through the mountains of time. Money gained on the quest will help rebuild the villages after respect is restored.

This trailer illustrates how the game is played.
Under the category ‘Primary Games’, Tea Tree Gully Primary School’s Liam Blake and Christopher Halse, Grade 5, were the Screen It 2011 winners.

results.title: Sergeant Swell of the Mounties
results.creator_credit: Chuck Menville, Len Janson and Pending Productions
results.brief_description: A spoof on the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in which our hero, Sergeant Swell, finds himself at odds with a local Indian tribe and a warrior who always seems to be just a few steps behind. Includes the ‘cliche’ lady in perpetual distress who requires continuous rescuing by the incompetent Swell.

description_for_label: A spoof on the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in which our hero, Sergeant Swell, finds himself at odds with a local Indian tribe and a warrior who always seems to be just a few steps behind. Includes the ‘cliche’ lady in perpetual distress who requires continuous rescuing by the incompetent Swell.

results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Caught In The Crowd
results.creator_credit: India Thompson and Norwood Primary School
results.brief_description:
Piper and Nick were best friends from a young age but as they grew up, Piper became one of the most popular girls in the school and studious Nick fell into the nerdy group. School bullies harass Nick while Piper looks on concerned. She is torn when Nick calls to her for help. Will Piper risk her popularity to respect their life-long friendship, or will she be caught in the crowd?
Written and directed by India Thompson with Film Support by Michael Hilbert and Sue Chapple. Cast includes: Piper Adams, Nicholas House, Emma Johnstone and Cameron Wicks.
Under the category ‘Primary Live Action’, Norwood Primary School’s 5/6 Chapple/Dennis class were the Screen It 2011 winners.
